body:
Hi @nstuyvesant I haven't seen that before. Unfortinatly the line it refers to does not help much, since that is the point at which Express.js code calls your user-land code. We can take a look, though. Can you provide the following?

1. The version of Node.js you're using
2. The version of this module you're using
3. Complete code I can run to reproduce the issue
4. Complete instructions on how to run your code to reproduce the issue

Thank you!

Sure thing...
1. Node: 7.7.4
2. ExpressJS 4.15.2
Let me try to carve out a minimal example - lots of layers to all of this. More on that shortly.

Here's a full stack trace but again, I'll work on putting together a shorter example:

```
(node:63908) Warning: a promise was created in a handler at /Users/nates/Documents/Development/shy/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:317:13 but was not returned from it, see http://goo.gl/rRqMUw
```

Thanks for the stack trace, @nstuyvesant . The hard part is that Express itself does not make use of Promises, and the only parts of Express in your stack are just the boundaries where Express calls your user-land code, so without understanding what the user-land code is, it's hard to say. I'm also not sure if ultimately it is anything Express could fix at all; it may just perhaps be an issue in the user-land code that just needs to be resolved, but since Express calls your code, it of course shows up in the stack traces :)

Hey @nstuyvesant, if I could just interject briefly as I use bluebird as well and rely on this warning to catch some careless mistakes. 

Firstly this is a description of this specific warning, what causes it (in general), and a few workarounds: http://bluebirdjs.com/docs/warning-explanations.html#warning-a-promise-was-created-in-a-handler-but-was-not-returned-from-it

Normally, one would always want to be returning their promises as to not accidentally be swallowing errors or returns (although there are use cases not to, ofc). One awkward case when dealing with Express 4 is within a route context, as you want to start your chain with Promise.try() but at the same time you can't _return_ this promise chain from the route (as it's a callback). This is usually the situation where you'll see this warning using express and what I suspect is happening here.

One "solution" is to use [`express-promise-router`](https://github.com/express-promise-router/express-promise-router), which affords you the ability to return a promise from your router (by extending the core express router) which should shut up this warning. Also you get the benefit of (what is more or less) `next(err)` if an error is thrown from your returned chain.

Finally, you're going to want to return whatever the ultimate response path is of this chain (whether a res.render, next call, or similar) to keep this warning suppressed. Alternatively, you can use `return null` like in the post i linked to above. Cheers.
